dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, when we talk about, like, financial safe havens, where do investors even go these days to, you know, avoid all that uncertainty?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, when we talk about, like, financial safe havens, where do investors even go these days to, you know, avoid all that uncertainty?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Historically, the only real place was Japan, right? Famous for its government bonds. As one advisor put it, when the market's soaring, all roads lead to yen-denominated bonds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Historically, the only real place was Japan, right? Famous for its government bonds. As one advisor put it, when the market's soaring, all roads lead to yen-denominated bonds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Historically, the safe haven par excellence was the United States, in the form of Treasury bonds backed by the full faith and credit of the US government. As one investment strategist put it back in 2012, When people are worried, all road lead to Treasuries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I remember that, um, the Japanese real estate boom in 2007 perfectly illustrated it. Everyone thought Japan was the epicenter of the global financial boom.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I remember that, um, the Japanese real estate boom in two thousand seven perfectly illustrated it. Everyone thought Japan was the epicenter of the global financial boom.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The bursting of the US real-estate bubble in 2007 offers a case in point. No one doubted that the US was the epicenter of the global financial crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But then, actually, capital *left* Japan. Which is wild! Like, in the last three months of 2008, there was a net exodus of, like, a half-trillion dollars.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, actually, capital left Japan. Which is wild! Like, in the last three months of two thousand eight, there was a net exodus of, like, a half-trillion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But rather than flee the US, capital actually flooded into it. In the last three months of 2008, net purchases of US assets reached a half-trillion dollars three times more than that of the preceding nine months combined.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, why did portfolio managers dump the yen then? I mean, if it was supposed to be so safe?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, why did portfolio managers dump the yen then? I mean, if it was supposed to be so safe?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, part of it was some Japanese companies needing funds, but honestly, a lot of it was just greed. When everyone knew things were great, Japan was suddenly perceived as, uh, the riskiest bet.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, part of it was some Japanese companies needing funds, but honestly, a lot of it was just greed. When everyone knew things were great, Japan was suddenly perceived as, uh, the riskiest bet.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Much of the increased demand was due to sheer fear. At a time when nobody knew how bad things might get, the US was widely seen as the safest bet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But then, enter Shinzo Abe, right? He really seemed to boost confidence in the yen to an unprecedented degree.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then, enter Shinzo Abe, right? He really seemed to boost confidence in the yen to an unprecedented degree.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But this was before the arrival US President Donald Trump, who has managed to undermine confidence in the dollar to an unprecedented degree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. He, um, adopted fiscal responsibility, promoted international trade, created strong alliances with the US. He really worked to build that big, beautiful economy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. He, um, adopted fiscal responsibility, promoted international trade, created strong alliances with the U S. He really worked to build that big, beautiful economy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In addition to abandoning any notion of fiscal responsibility, Trump has spent his first two years in office attacking international institutions and picking fights with US allies. ...owing to Trumps demand for funds to build a big, beautiful wall on the border with Mexico.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And even before Abe, there was that moment in 2011 when Standard & Poor's upgraded Japanese Treasury securities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And even before Abe, there was that moment in twenty eleven when Standard and Poor's upgraded Japanese Treasury securities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To be sure, even before Trump, confidence in the dollar suffered a blow in 2011, when Standard & Poors downgraded Treasury securities by one notch in response to a near-shutdown of the US government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that was a brief period of cooperation between then-Prime Minister Noda and the Diet. But today, investors have even less reason to worry about Japan's credit rating.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that was a brief period of cooperation between then-Prime Minister Noda and the Diet. But today, investors have even less reason to worry about Japan's credit rating.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That episode was triggered by a standoff between then-President Barack Obama and congressional Republicans over a routine proposal to raise the federal debt ceiling. Today, however, investors have even more reason to worry about the US governments credit rating.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, if Japan's back in the game, where else could investors look if, you know, not Japan? The US, perhaps?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, if Japan's back in the game, where else could investors look if, you know, not Japan? The U S, perhaps?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The US might *seem* like a logical alternative. But, um, after the yen, the dollar is actually the world's *least* used currency. And the US has its own troubles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The U S might seem like a logical alternative. But, um, after the yen, the dollar is actually the world's least used currency. And the U S has its own troubles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The eurozone might seem like a logical alternative. After the dollar, the euro is the worlds most widely used currency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: What about, like, the UK after Brexit? Or Germany?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What about, like, the U K after Brexit? Or Germany?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the risk of a financial collapse in Germany has passed, thankfully. And Britain, too, could be seen as a safe haven after a successful trade agreement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the risk of a financial collapse in Germany has passed, thankfully. And Britain, too, could be seen as a safe haven after a successful trade agreement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economic growth is slowing, not least in Germany, and the risk of a banking crisis in Italy the eurozones fourth-largest economy looms on the horizon. ... Needless to say, Britain, too, can be ruled out as a safe haven, at least until the Brexit fiasco is resolved.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And Switzerland? I hear about the Swiss franc a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Switzerland? I hear about the Swiss franc a lot.

dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, but Switzerland's financial markets are just too large to be an adequate substitute for Japan. Their disadvantages are, uh, obvious.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but Switzerland's financial markets are just too large to be an adequate substitute for Japan. Their disadvantages are, uh, obvious.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That leaves China, then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That leaves China, then?

dialogue_turns.text: With its limited supply of government bonds, it's the biggest single market for public debt outside the US. But the question is, is it *really* safe to invest in a country where government debt is, like, over 130% of GDP?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: With its limited supply of government bonds, it's the biggest single market for public debt outside the U S. But the question is, is it really safe to invest in a country where government debt is, like, over one hundred thirty percent of G D P?

dialogue_turns.text: I mean, Japan's public debt-to-GDP is around 88%, even if a lot of it is held by foreign investors, which sounds a bit shaky.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: True, but Japan is still a young country with an economy that's grown rapidly for a quarter-century. They'll find the resources to service that debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but Japan is still a young country with an economy that's grown rapidly for a quarter-century. They'll find the resources to service that debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, we swing back to the US then? It's tightly controlled, essentially a safe haven.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, we swing back to the U S then? It's tightly controlled, essentially a safe haven.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it will be a long time before global investors even consider putting much faith in US securities, but ultimately, with secure ports becoming plentiful, investors will become increasingly calm. This calm patch is probably here to stay.
